projectDesc.p: The Greenfield Digital Project interprets the story of Bankers Trust Company, a large Philadelphia bank that failed in 1930, through a selection of primary source documents, contextual essays, and teacher resources. The project is part of a larger effort funded by the Albert M. Greenfield Foundation to make HSP's 20th-century holdings more accessible.

editorialDecl.p: This electronic file was created using manual keying following the recommendations for Level 4 of "Best Practices for TEI in Libraries" guidelines v3.0.

We have generally encoded entire documents/texts, not excerpts. We have encoded page breaks. We have also preserved original spelling, typographical errors, missing text, and original capitalization. For clippings from newspapers or other publications, we have transcribed just the text related to the article, ignoring other text or markings on the page that were purposefully or inadvertently included during clipping. We have regularized spacing between words and sentences to replace double (or triple) spaces to a single space.
We have not coded line breaks, end-of-line hyphenation, visual rendition of layout, font changes, or text alignment (left, right, center).

note.add: From the Jewish World issue of 12/19/30

div.head: EXPLANATION WITH REGARDS TO THE LIQUIDATION OF THE BANK OF PHILADELPHIA AND TRUST COMPANY.
div.p: Through a regrettable Printer's error that crept into an article of news that appeared in day before yesterday's issue of the "Jewish World" regarding the "Bank of Philadelphia and Trust Company", a mis-statement was made in connection with that Bank. It is, therefore, of great importance that the false statement that appeared in the news be corrected.

July last, the Bankers Trust Company, one of the largest Banks in Philadelphia, took over the job of liquidating all the resources of the Bank of Philadelphia and Trust Company, turning it into cash so that the Stockholders of the Bank of Philadelphia and Trust Company would receive the largest amount of cash for their stock. A short time ago the Bankers Trust Company sent a letter to the Stockholders of the Bank of Philadelphia and Trust Company advising them of the progress that was being made. The letter read as follows:
"To the Stockholders of the Bank of Philadelphia and Trust Company:-

The liquidation of the Bank of Philadelphia and Trust Company as it is being arranged and carried out by the Bankers Trust Company for your benefit, has reached a stage that it is now possible to give you information to which you are entitled.

On July 21st, 1930, when your Bank ceased doing business, the Bankers Trust Company, in accordance with the agreement, paid the debts which your Bank owed to other Banks and also assumed the liability for all deposits that were then in your Bank. Your Bank at that time received from the Bankers Trust Company a loan of $17,962,247.82, for which amount the Bank of Philadelphia and Trust Company put up as security their assets worth $23,655,727.20. This loan represented a sum of money equal to the amount of money the Bank of Philadelphia and Trust Company owed to other Banks and to their depositors.

Since then the assets of the Bank of Philadelphia and Trust Company, which were deposited with us, were turned into cash, the result being that your Bank has already paid us off $10,113,895.17 of the loan.

The book worth of other assets of your Bank that still remain with us is $15,186,995.55, which consists of Securities, Loans on Collateral, Mortgages, Real Estate and Commercial Paper. Even though the biggest portion of these assets are good, however, a goodly part of the same are of doubtful worth, and it will require some time to liquidate in order to obtain the most cash therefor.

After the liquidating process has been completed and your Bank pays us off the balance of our loan and all their other debts are paid, the balance will be turned back to you as Stockholders. How large your share will be cannot be known until the liquidation has been completed; however, taking into consideration what has already been accomplished, and from what information we have regarding Real Estate Appraisements and Loans, we can now say that you, the Stockholders, will receive much more than it was thought you could possibly receive some time ago.
(Signed) SAMUEL H. BARKER, President, Bankers Trust Co. of Philadelphia."

Naturally, the depositors,as well as the Stockholders of the Bank of Philadelphia and Trust Company, were highly satisfied that the Bankers Trust Company, one of the largest Banks of Philadelphia and a member of the Clearing House Association, undertook the above job, offering itself as a bulkwark of security for the best interests of all.
